Posts.Title: Why Targeting Fast-Growing Cancer Cells Might Not Always Work Bestbird

Posts.Content: Mompsych wrote: I responded well to tamoxifen after my initial dx in 2002 and did the then typical 5 years of treatment with it. Never felt well on any of the AIs and so after the bilateral mastectomy and CMF chemo as well as the 5 years of tamoxifen, we decided that it was ok to stop the AI treatment. Well, that didn't work out. 2 years later,- mets in my hips and spine. I restarted on an AI; TMs kept rising; tried Faslodex with no response and finally started on Abraxane (also have been on Xeloda). After my TMs started rising after the Xeloda, my Onc put my on An A/A combo and the numbers kept going up. Since I had done so well on the tamoxifen, I searched for articles that used an everolimus and tamoxifen combo. Found one! Here it is: jco.ascopubs.org/content/early/2012/05/03/JCO.2011.39.0708.full.pdf To make a long story short, I am on an Everolimus/ tamoxifen combo and my TMs are going down! So, if you are not doing well on the A/A combo and you responded well to tamoxifen in the past, this is a treatment you may want to consider. Dx 4/2002, ILC, Right, 1cm, Stage IV, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 5/5/2002 Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left Chemotherapy Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy Halaven (eribulin) Surgery Prophylactic ovary removal Chemotherapy Abraxane (albumin-bound or nab-paclitaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Everolimus (Afinitor) and Tamoxifen; NOT an AI Mompsych Tomboy

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2014 08:36AM Mompsych wrote: Jill andFluff Yuck! Haven't been here for a bit and just saw your post.  Nausea is the worst.  Pot brownies, ginger, scopolamine patches and sea bands are all worth a try.  Before you go for the scopolamine patch, you might want to try Dramamine or bonine. They both help with nausea as well.  Benzodiazepines (like Xanax and Ativan) also help with nausea, so they are also worth a try. They can make you sleepy - so you may have to fiddle with the dose.  So sorry you both are going through this...

Posts.Content: Mompsych wrote: Just got back from my every 2 week blood level appointment and my numbers (CEA, CA27/29, CTCs) went down.  Last visit they were up after having consistently going down on Xeloda, which I have been on since October, 2013.  Before I was on Xeloda, I was on abraxane.  It worked for a while and then my numbers slowly stated creeping up and eventually I had to switch to the Xeloda.  I was so worried that the trend was going to go up again and I would have to start a 3rd chemo treatment.  I know that I shouldn't live by the numbers and try to look at the big picture, but AAAARGGHH - it's so hard not to feel like I've been punched in the stomach when I hear those damn numbers.  Today was such a relief!  I'm not so good at this "one day at a time" thing. I try - just too neurotic.  Always waiting for that other shoe to drop.  Gotta work on this... Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2015 06:16PM Mompsych wrote: Bon I too have a lot of stomach issues; the last 2 endoscopies I've had have shown ILC cells throughout my stomach. I live outside New York City and after one visit to Sloane Kettering, have avoided it like the plague. There are many other people around here that feel the same way that I do. It is so important to find someone who really listens! Good luck with all of this... Marian

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2013 06:48AM Mompsych wrote: hi danishgirl66 Sorry to hear about your progression. I also was dx'ed with ILC cells lining my stomach after an endoscopy (I also have bone mets).  I was on tamoxifen and arimedex initialy for about 7 uears beore the bome mets appeared. My first shot at chemo was abraxane, which worked for about 6 months, then my TMs started to slowly creep up.  I am now on Xeloda which I am tolerating a bit more easily, and so far, so good. I have been on it since October.  I think we each respond to various chemos differently, so unfortunately I can't predict how this will effect you. Isn't uncertainty just peachy?!? Are you having GI symptoms?  Good luck with the next step.

Posts.Title: got some good news this evening chris1959 sandilee

Posts.Content: Mompsych wrote:  I sent this email to a bunch of people to see if I could get some donations for MBC. I'll see if it works. Please feel free to email it to anyone else if you want to give it a go.  I set up a new gmail account with the name metastaticmarian (couldn't help myself).   Hello all, There is a t-shirt printed for those with metastatic breast cancer (MBC) that in a continual loop says Scan >Treat >Repeat >.What it really should say is Scan >have horrible anticipatory anxiety until you get the results, with moments of black despair. Brace yourself, find out results and either continue with current treatment regimen or find that your disease has progressed and start a new treatment that has its own wonderful world of side effects; sob quietly for a bit >Repeat >. Harder to fit that on a t-shirt though... The sad reality is that approximately ONE in THREE women who have had invasive breast cancer will eventually develop metastatic disease. It can occur anytime after the initial treatment. Five years clean is NOT a cure; i.e., I was diagnosed approximately 7 years after a double mastectomy and chemotherapy. As we end the month of October, I think we can pretty much agree that we are all "aware" of breast cancer. All those pink ribbons and rah-rah survivor attitudes do not help the tens of thousand of women with MBC. Currently MBC-focused research makes up only 7% of money invested in all of breast cancer studies. So, here I am making a plea for you to donate. I hate to ask, but for me and so many others, it is literally a matter of life or death. I have conveniently provided a website for you in which you click "Get Involved" and then "donate" and send what you wish. Here it is: mbcn.org Then - please send this email to five other generous souls to get the word out. I hope people will keep forwarding this, so that if nothing else, people will understand a bit more about metastatic disease. NO more pink t-shirts, pink ribbons, pink shoelaces, pink PF Chang's horses (I mean, really???). Just a cure. Many, many, thanks Marian Dx 4/2002, ILC, Right, 1cm, Stage IV, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 5/5/2002 Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left Chemotherapy Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy Halaven (eribulin) Surgery Prophylactic ovary removal Chemotherapy Abraxane (albumin-bound or nab-paclitaxel) Log in to post a reply

I finally talked over her her and said, "you HAVE to stop NOW!"  She stopped.  "I have cancer and we donate money and I don't want to get this call again!" Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2014 01:39PM Mompsych wrote: Hi Raro, Really great post - also something I have felt a lot lately. It feels like lack of energy vs. purpose, and lack of energy mostly seems to win. I work one day a week now, but the rest of my time is pretty unstructured. Daytime tv IS mostly yucky, but it happen to love the daily show and Stephen Colbert, so I DVR them and watch them the next day. Boredom and frustration reign though. I just feel like I'm in limbo all the time. My kids are in college now so I also lack that daily running around (and I miss them!). Ms M has good suggestions... I am trying to find things to do and drag myself to them if I can. I usually find that if I can get out a bit, I do feel better even though I am wiped out. This is a tough one, with no easy answers...

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2013 09:15PM Mompsych wrote: Hi Lynne, I am currently taking abraxane, which is notorious for neuropathic side effects. Every time I have chemo, I put on little booties with flexible ice packs in them, as well as wrap my hands in something called elastogel that I have put in the freezer. I also plop a bag of frozen peas on top of my feet. I got both of these things on amazon.com, or you could also google something like "ice packs for feet/hands." These constrict the blood vessels in your hands and feet, so you don't get as much of the chemo circulating in there. It has really worked! I get funny looks, but no neuropathy! This has worked for 6 months and I hope it continues. Also, try taking B6... Neurontin does wonders for some people too. Good luck with all of this.

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2014 12:22AM Mompsych wrote: I have not had bone pain thus far either. Not grat reactions to all the chemos and surgeries, but that is to be expected. Benjnate - there are still a lot of options out there for you. There are many different chemo meds out there, and any one of them could get to to NED.  I have been on abraxane ( a taxol type drug) and am now on xeloda.  I'm almost afraid to say it, but my TMs are going down and my last few CTCs were at 1 or 0.  don't count yourself out! Maybe a second opinion would be helpful.

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2014 09:33PM Mompsych wrote: Musiclover Great suggestions from all of the above...but also, it is totally normal to have those moments of panic and/or misery.  Don't beat yourself up about it. Sometimes a good old fashioned cry is what you need.  Glad to hear your tx went better today.  One thing that I have been doing is getting out and seeing music and broadway shows.  I have this memory that you are out in Long Island (yes/no?).  I schlep into the city and mostly go to matinees. There is a very good website that had discount tickets for a number of shows - broadwaybox.com  Also recently went into this little cabaret/piano bar with a friend and it was really fun.  Do what lifts your spirits!  Also pick a drug, any drug that eases things for you.  Antidepressants, anti-anxiety meds, marijuana, gin and tonic (very nice in the summer), etc. I agree with Dbla-  if you are not finding this therapist helpful - find another one!  You are the consumer here and you want someone who can help you cope with all of this.  It might be helpful to get a recommendation from your Onc's  office, Gilda's club or the American Cancer Society. Hang in there!

Posts.Content: May 8, 2014 08:02PM Mompsych wrote: frankly, I would get a second opinion.  I am of the notion that the more you can keep at bay as early as possible, the better.  If there is progression of disease, why wouldn't your Onc try to stop it in its tracks? Of course,it would probably mean some sort of chemotherapy, which has its own wonderful side effects. Maybe your onc doesn't feel like its enough of a progression yet.  Does he also check TMs and CTCs?
